layer.name: Discipline
layer.definition: Do what needs doing, especially when you don't feel like it.

questions.principle: Feel the rollercoaster, don't act on the rollercoaster

answers.4: usually feel without acting impulsively, though strong ones can still hijack me
answers.5: feel them fully — and then choose my response
answers.2: push them down — if they're important I'll deal with them later
answers.3: manage some well, but others (anger, anxiety) still control me
answers.1: act on them — when I feel it, I do it

answers.4: usually processed, though some get buried longer than they should
answers.2: avoided — I prefer distraction to the discomfort
answers.3: sometimes processed, but often left to build until they overflow
answers.1: buried — if I don't think about them, they don't exist

answers.4: usually pause, though occasionally I react first
answers.5: pause automatically — I've trained myself to create space
answers.2: rarely pause — I react and regret later
answers.3: pause sometimes, but strong triggers still get instant reactions
answers.1: react immediately — the words are out before I think

answers.4: mostly moving, talking, or creating — occasionally numbing
answers.5: outlets that restore me — I've built them and I use them
answers.3: a mix — depends on how bad it is
answers.1: numbing — food, drink, screens, whatever stops the feeling

questions.text: When something bothers me in a relationship, I ...

answers.4: usually address it fairly promptly, though sometimes I delay
answers.5: address it quickly — resentment can't build if I don't let it
answers.2: might address it eventually, but usually let it fester too long
answers.3: address some things, avoid the really uncomfortable ones
answers.1: avoid it — resentment builds until something breaks

remediation.advice: The goal isn't to stop feeling - it's to stop letting feelings control actions. Start a simple practice: when triggered, name the emotion out loud ('I'm feeling angry'), take three breaths, then choose your response. As Cloud & Townsend teach: emotions are data, not directives.

scripture.text: Whoever is slow to anger is better than the mighty, and he who rules his spirit than he who takes a city.
